Svaha Oá¹ƒ HÅ«á¹ƒ Phaá¹­ Svaha This vidya-raja always secretly protects with majestic virtue.
All that is done is accomplished.
At that time, Shakyamuni Tathagata, the Right and Perfectly Enlightened One,
Immediately at that time, universally emitted a flame-garland pure light.
It universally illuminated the trichiliocosm.
It burned the palaces of all Mara kings.
The blazing flames surrounded it, becoming a single mass of fire, burning it to nothing.
At that time, the Mara kings, due to the power of their own karma, were unwilling to submit.
These Mara kings and their Mara retinues,
Turned and gave rise to poison and harm, each with angry thoughts.
They held sharp swords, bows, arrows, knives, discuses, and various weapons in their hands.
At that time, Vajrapani, the Lord of Secrets, as the Buddha manifested,
Passed through worlds to the east, twenty-one times the number of sands in the Ganges River.
All the Mara kings were completely subdued.
His body was red, his eyes were green, and his four fangs protruded.
Frowning, glaring, with hair standing up like vermilion.
With great majestic virtue, holding a staff with the right hand.
Holding a vajra with the left hand.
Adorned with dragons, wearing a tiger skin.
In this way, in the south, west, and north,
In worlds equal to twenty-one Ganges Rivers in number,
He manifested his body and subdued them all.
At that time, countless koá¹­is of nayutas of hundreds of thousands of millions of poisonous MÄra kings,
Were subdued by the powerful vidyÄ-rÄja.
Terrified, trembling, with confused minds,
With no strength in the four limbs, unaware of anything,
Neglecting their bodies and lives, the MÄra kings were bound by their own karmic actions in five ways.
At that time, VajrapÄá¹‡i, the Lord of Secrets, having done this,
Immediately the hosts of the night demons, the Tuá¹£ita gods, the NirmÄá¹‡arati gods, and the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin gods,
Each holding various ointments, incense,
And various wonderful flowers, banners, canopies, went
To where ÅšÄkyamuni TathÄgata was to make offerings.
Circumambulated the Buddha to the right and then sat to one side.
At that time, VajrapÄá¹‡i Bodhisattva,
Having praised and extolled the TathÄgatas,
The great wisdom of the TathÄgata, within the supreme great teaching,
Uttered the mantra of immeasurable majestic virtue, courage, and great power, which accomplishes all wishes as one desires,
In order to benefit and bring peace and happiness to all beings in the heavens and the human realm.
Then he spoke the mantra, saying:
